article:
In heraldry, a 'compartment' is a design placed under the shield, usually rocks,
a grassy mount (mount vert), or some sort of other landscape upon which the
supporters are depicted as standing. Woodcock, Thomas and Robinson, John
Martin, The Oxford Guide to Heraldry (1990), p106 Care must be taken to
distinguish true compartments from items upon which supporters are merely
resting one or more feet, or, sometimes, mere heraldic badges or pure decoration
under the shield, and, conversely, care must also be taken in very unusual cases
such as the coat of arms of Belize, in which what may be taken to be a crest,
the mahogany tree rising above the shield, is really part of the compartment. It
is sometimes said to represent the land held by the bearer. As an official part
of the blazon it is a comparatively late feature of heraldry, often derived from
the need to have different supporters for different families or entities,
although sometimes the compartment is treated in the blazon separately from the
supporters.
